Title: The Penguin Book of the Prose Poem
Author: Jeremy Noel-Tod
HighlightText: Outer sounds like traffic and shoveling vanish. Inner sounds become audible, cracks, sighs, caresses, twigs, birdbreath, toenails of squirrel.

Title: The Penguin Book of the Prose Poem
Author: Jeremy Noel-Tod

Title: The Penguin Book of the Prose Poem
Author: Jeremy Noel-Tod
HighlightText: It was the lever between inner and outer worlds, it showed that the airs and waters, rocks and earth, moving and combining and resisting one another, obeying the spirits that ruled them, had their equivalent workings, their times of calm and upheaval, under the skin; in the wallowing lungs, the weeping flesh, the flowing heart, and in all the symmetries of bones and muscles, the asymmetries of lower organs, the random belt of the guts. It brought the cross-sections of life within grasp. Behind it, the physician’s trial and error, the surgeon’s initiative; the whole breathing, faltering body of science.

Title: The Penguin Book of the Prose Poem
Author: Jeremy Noel-Tod
HighlightText: Gross desire is a river tapestry with water like ribbons – he tells me.

Title: The Penguin Book of the Prose Poem
Author: Jeremy Noel-Tod
HighlightText:
Hers is not a world of surfaces – skin, husks, bark with definite edges and identities.
Trees appear as columns of light melting into surroundings where form is discerned, but is glowing, transparent, mingling like breath.
She tends to a plant by maintaining fusion between the plant’s form and life-vitality contained within.

Title: The Penguin Book of the Prose Poem
Author: Jeremy Noel-Tod
HighlightText:
To plant a garden is to believe in tomorrow.
 – Amana Colony, Iowa

Title: The Penguin Book of the Prose Poem
Author: Jeremy Noel-Tod
HighlightText:
To light a lamp is to hide darkness in the same closet as sleep, along with silence, desire, and yesterday’s obsessions. To read a book is to marry two solitudes, the way a conversation erases and erects, words prepare for wordlessness, a cloud for its own absence, and snow undresses for spring.
The bedroom is where you left it, although the creases and humps on the sheets no longer share your outline and worldview. In that way, they are like the children you never had time for.

Title: The Penguin Book of the Prose Poem
Author: Jeremy Noel-Tod
HighlightText:
Walls hold peace as much as distance. A kettle is not reason enough for tears.
The correct answer to a mirror is always, yes.

Title: The Penguin Book of the Prose Poem
Author: Jeremy Noel-Tod

Title: The Penguin Book of the Prose Poem
Author: Jeremy Noel-Tod
HighlightText: No matter who two are kissing, eternity arrives, jelly bean eyes black crystal balls. The longer we look, the more we recognize and anything we could say is too obvious. The songs we like are the songs we know, and every song on the radio is about us.
